questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal lady presents with simple endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. What is management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hysterectomy For simple hyperplasia with atypia and complex hyperplasia with atypia, the risks of malignant transformation are 8% and 29% respectively. Therefore, we prefer a hysterectomy unless the woman wants to preserve the uterus. Here the age is 55 years so definitely no use of the uterus and therefore option A.

Highyeild:

Endometriosis versus Adenomyosis Variable Endometriosis Adenomyosis Definition Functional endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterus. Endometrial tissue in the myometrium of the uterus. History/PE Cyclic pelvic and/or rectal pain and dyspareunia. Uterus not enlarged but painful nodules, restricted range of motion. The classic triad of pain, menorrhagia, and an enlarged, boggy, symmetric uterus. Diagnosis • Requires direct visualization by laparoscopy or laparotomy. • MRI can aid in diagnosis but is costly. • Classic lesions have a blue-black (“raspberry”) or dark brown (“powder-burned”) appearance. • Ultrasonography is useful but cannot always distinguish between leiomyoma and adenomyosis. • The ovaries may have endometriomas (“chocolate cysts”). • Ultimately a pathologic diagnosis. Treatment • Pharmacologic: Inhibits ovulation. Combination OCPs (first line), GnRH analogues (Leuprolide), Danazol, NSAIDs, or progestins. • Pharmacologic: Largely symptomatic relief. NSAIDs (first line) plus OCPs or progestins. • Conservative surgical treatment: Excision, cauterization, or ablation of the lesions and lysis of adhesions. Twenty per cent of patients can become pregnant subsequent to treatment. • Conservative surgical treatment: Endometrial ablation or resection using hysteroscopy. Complete eradication of deep adenomyosis is difficult and results in  treatment failure. • Definitive surgical treatment: TAH/BSO ± lysis of adhesions. • Definitive surgical treatment: Hysterectomy is the only definitive treatment. Complications Infertility (the most common cause among menstruating women >30 years of age). May rarely progress to endometrial carcinoma. Types of Endometrial Cancer Variable Type I: Endometrioid Type II: Serous Epidemiology 75% of endometrial cancers 25% of endometrial cancers Etiology Unopposed estrogen stimulation (e.g., tamoxifen use, exogenous estrogen-only therapy) Unrelated to estrogen; the p53 mutation is present in 90% of cases Precursor lesion Hyperplasia and atypical hyperplasia None Mean age at diagnosis 55 years 67 years Prognosis Favourable Poor

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false.

questions.text: All of the following are reversible long-acting contraceptives except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Laparoscopic tubal ligation

Highyeild:

Long-acting reversible contraception (LARC) includes implants and intrauterine devices. Both give long-lasting contraceptive fertility. Laparoscopic tubal ligation is the most common modality of pregnancy prevention. It is irreversible in nature. Spring-loaded clips (Filshie clip, Hulka clip) or Silastic rubber bands (Falope ring) are most commonly used. Destruction or removal of a segment of the oviduct is performed in an operating room through a transabdominal approach usually using a laparoscopy or mini-laparotomy. An ectopic pregnancy should be ruled out if the procedure fails. The failure rate is 1 in 200.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are reversible.

Extraedge:

Laparoscopic Technique Implanon Nexplanon/Implanon is a long-acting injectable contraception. It is an implant inserted beneath the skin of the upper arm and is effective for 3 years. It prevents ovulation in addition to impaired oocyte maturation and thickened cervical mucus. Amenorrhea, irregular vaginal bleeding, weight gain, alopecia, reduced libido, depression, and osteopenia are the side effects.

questions.text: Which of the following is not in the quadruple test for antenatal detection of Down syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inhibin B

Highyeild:

Quadruple Marker Screen Second-trimester screening uses a panel of biochemical markers to adjust the maternal age-related risk for fetal aneuploidy. The standard “quadruple panel” test at 15–20 weeks uses four markers : α-fetoprotein (AFP), β hCG, inhibin A, and estriol. The most important variable is gestational age which accounts for most false-positive results. Trisomy Screening The 80% sensitivity increased for trisomy 21 detection by performing a maternal serum screen for not only MS-AFP, but also hCG, estriol, and inhibin-A. The window for testing is also 15–20 weeks. Trisomy 21 Levels of MS-AFP and estriol are decreased in Down syndrome , but levels of hCG and inhibin-A are increased. Amniocentesis is performed for checking the karyotype. Trisomy 18 Levels for all 4 markers (MS-AFP, estriol, inhibin-A, and hCG) are decreased in Edward syndrome. Amniocentesis is performed for checking the karyotype. Quadruple Screening MS-AFP Estriol Inhibin A Β-hCG Trisomy 18 ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ Trisomy 21 ↓ ↓ ↑ ↑

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and D are included in the quadruple test.

questions.text: What should be the time of termination of pregnancy of a female with insulin-dependent diabetes?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

40 weeks In diabetic mothers, there is a delay in the maturation of the fetal lung due to a delay in the completion of surfactant formation. Hence, 40 weeks is the choice— the expected delivery can be delayed up to 40 weeks.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and C are false.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female was diagnosed with CIN-3. What will be the management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Colposcopy + LEEP Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) is the most common method. The procedure is done under local anaesthesia and removes, rather than destroys, the affected tissue—allowing for diagnosis and treatment during a single visit.

Highyeild:

Pap Smear Classification Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance (ASC-US) It is an indeterminate smear. Changes suggestive of but not adequate to label LSIL Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) A biopsy is expected to show histologic findings of mild dysplasia, HPV, or CIN 1 High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) A biopsy is expected to show histologic findings of moderate-severe dysplasia, CIN 2, CIN 3, or CIS Squamous cell carcinoma A biopsy is expected to show histologic findings of invasive cancer Classification of cervical dysplasias Management of Abnormal Histology Steps in management Stages Management details Observation and follow-up CIN 1 CIN 2 or 3 after ablation or excision Repeat Pap in 6 and 12 months; colposcopy and repeat Pap in 12 months; or HPV DNA testing in 12 months Ablative modalities CIN 2 or 3 These include: • Cryotherapy (freezing) • Laser vaporization, and • Electrofulguration Excisional procedures Note : These are superior to ablative modalities CIN 2 or 3 These include: • LEEP (loop electrosurgical excision procedure) • Cold-knife conization Hysterectomy • Recurrent CIN 2 or 3 • Biopsy confirmed if less than stage II

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and C are false.

questions.text: Possible causes of choriocarcinoma after the hydatidiform mole are all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Suburethral nodule

Highyeild:

Choriocarcinoma consists of sheets of anaplastic cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast cells without chorionic villi. Metastases are always choriocarcinoma. Choriocarcinomas are commonly accompanied by ovarian theca lutein cysts. Choriocarcinoma is seen in postmenopausal women. Pelvic mass is also palpable. ↑ hCG level is seen in choriocarcinoma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and C are possible causes of choriocarcinoma after a hydatidiform mole.

questions.text: Active management of the third stage of labour includes all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Uterine massage

Highyeild:

Stages of Labor Duration Stage Starts/ Ends Primiparous Multiparous Abnormalities 1 st Latent The onset of labour to 3–4 cm dilation 6–11 hours 4–8 hours Prolongation seen with excessive sedation and hypotonic uterine contractions. Management: Rest and sedation Active 4 cm to complete cervical dilation (10 cm) 4–6 hours (1.2 cm/h) 2–3 hours (1.5 cm/h) Prolongation: Cervical dilation of <1.2 cm/h (primipara)/<1.5 cm/h (multipara) Arrest: No cervical change in ≥ 2 hours Cause: This abnormality is seen in a passenger (fetal size or abnormal presentation), pelvis, or power (dysfunctional contractions) Management: IV oxytocin → Hypotonic contractions Emergency cesarean section → Adequate contractions 2 nd Complete cervical dilation to delivery of the infant 0.5–3.0 hours 5–30 minutes Second-stage arrest: • Failure to deliver within 1 hour (multipara) or 2 hours (nullipara) • Add an additional 1 hour if epidural Cause: This abnormality is seen in a passenger, pelvis, or power Management: • Cesarean → Fetal head is not engaged • Trial of obstetric forceps or vacuum extraction → Fetal head is engaged 3 rd Delivery of infant to delivery of the placenta 0–0.5 hour 0–0.5 hour Prolonged third stage: • Failure to deliver placenta within 30 minutes Cause: Consider placenta percreta/ accreta/increta Management : • IV oxytocin • If oxytocin fails, attempt manual removal • Hysterectomy may be needed

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are included in the active management of the third stage of labour.

questions.text: Before ovulation development of granules in a cell is dependent on:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Estrogen

Highyeild:

Estrogen is a steroid hormone which exists in three forms each of unique significance during a woman’s life. Estradiol is the most common moiety during the nonpregnant reproductive years. It is converted from androgens (produced from cholesterol in the follicular theca cells) which diffuse into the follicular granulosa cells containing the aromatase enzyme that completes the transformation into estradiol.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false.

Extraedge:

Estrogens Estradiol Nonpregnant reproductive years Follicle: Granulosa Estriol Pregnancy Placenta from fetal adrenal DHEAS Estrone After menopause Adipose from adrenal steroids

questions.text: A young female presents with a history of spontaneous abortions and secondary amenorrhea since then. FSH 6 IU/mL. What is the most probable cause of amenorrhea?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Uterine synechiae FSH within the normal limit rules out other options. Recurrent spontaneous abortions support the answer.

Highyeild:

Asherman Syndrome Intrauterine synechiae is also known as Asherman syndrome. This condition occurs due to vigorous uterine curettage in early pregnancy which may lead to scarring that interferes with normal endometrial growth and shedding. Asherman syndrome is classified as mild, moderate, or severe depending upon the degree and extent of adhesion. The patients present with secondary amenorrhea, hypomenorrhea, and infertility or habitual abortions. Hysteroscopy confirms uterine synechiae, type (flimsy or fibrous) and extent of adhesions. Treatment : Reformation of adhesions is prevented by insertion of IUCD for 3 months and giving estrogen cyclically (21 days) for 3 months to develop endometrium.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and C are false.

questions.text: Placenta grade 3, 35+3 weeks pregnancy, and absent end diastolic flow in Doppler. Next management is:

options.label: C
options.text: Talk with the paediatrician for termination

questions.correct_answer: A. Dexamethasone and terminate after 48 hours
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dexamethasone and terminate after 48 hours

Highyeild:

Antenatal Corticosteroid Therapy A single dose of corticosteroids is recommended for pregnant women with gestational age 23–34 weeks who are at risk of preterm delivery within 7 days. A complete course is - betamethasone two 1M 12 mg doses given 24 hours apart or dexamethasone four 1M 6 mg doses given 12 hours apart. Lower severity, frequency, or both of respiratory distress syndromes, intracranial haemorrhage, necrotizing enterocolitis, and death are seen in such “types of neonates whose mothers receive antenatal corticosteroids.”

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for vesicovaginal fistula is
questions.explanation:
Solution:

3 swab test

Highyeild:

Vesicovaginal Fistula The most common cause of bladder fistulae (80–90%) in India: Obstetrical problems . Prolonged labour—operative-vaginal cesarean section. Sometimes gynaecological cause: Hysterectomy, Sling operations for stress incontinence. Clinical features : Continuous dribbling of urine, no micturition (true incontinence). Investigation : Methylene swab test. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile swabs. 50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder through the catheter. If there is a VVF present, the methylene blue dye stains the uppermost swab. IVP : Normal in vesicovaginal fistula (VVF), but hydronephrosis on the affected side seen in the ureteric fistula.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and D are false.
